channel.title: Comments on: Eating out and religion
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Yonatan
item.dc:creator: Yonatan
item.description:
The financial and identity issues are always present. Eating out costs money.
Additionally, not eating out or eating out fosters an identity which is a mixture of religion/class/education/etc.
There is also the social aspect of eating out. Stay-at-home mothers in Borough Park & Flatbush socialize at pizza shops. Singles on the West Side at the Pizza Stores etc.
It is, for some, an alternative to Synagogues as a center for community, etc.

item.title: By: moshe shoshan
item.dc:creator: moshe shoshan
item.description: I think there is more here than economics. a generation or two ago kashrut created a culture in most locales of eating only at home. Now eating out at the local kosher eatery has real social/cultural significance. note the controversies in various frum communities about the appropriateness/value of a Kosher pizza place. I have heard people in Alon shvut say they are glad there is no pizza there like in efrat.

item.title: By: efrex
item.dc:creator: efrex
item.description:
Far too many unexplored variables to make this a worthwhile study on its own, IMHO, and of course, there's always the important <a href="http://xkcd.com/552/" rel="nofollow">caveat about correlation and causation</a>.
Assuming that there is a correlation between religiosity and income level, it's probably at least just as valid to say that the <b>former</b> determines the <b>latter</b> (i.e., more "frum" Jews eschew money-making opportunities, have larger families and hence less discretionary income, etc.)
It might also be interesting to survey <i>how often</i> people dine out as related to how much they spend. It's quite possible, for example, that religious families go out to eat no more than their non-religious counterparts, but due to (a) higher price of kosher food, and (b) larger number of mouths to feed, they wind up spending proportionally more per trip.
